title: Make a system of linking different pieces of content. A web of small and big content pieces linked together beautifully.
Donâ€™t focus too much on finding
one
i
superstrict niche. That will probably happen by itself after a year or two when I figure out which writings resonate the most with my readers.
What I want to write about on larskarbo.no:
There is something beautiful about keeping your entire blog in git. It makes it possible to time travel. I like that.
Coliving, best ways to live and work as humans
Should I treat everything I have written as a snapshot of a past. I wrote it the way I wrote it, even if I am ashamed of it now? One example is my
12 startups in 12 months
a
https://larskarbo.no/12-startups-12-months
post. I am not super happy about that post. The project is very cool, but the post is kind of shallow and not my best piece of content.
Should I keep things in git?
Have a beautifully designed and weird blog (
â€£
p
305be4b1-2dbb-4fb8-9f96-fe56481487b3
5257cf0b-8124-4419-87b6-815988437df5

When thinking of this now, I think I should try to leave old content as it is. Maybe update it and improve it the first weeks after publishing, but after that it should be considered a relic of the past. I can always add notes at the top or bottom linking to relevant new content or new takes on the idea if I feel the need.
I often end up unsure if I should keep old pieces of content up to date or not.
I have been interesting in writing for a long time. At least a couple of years.

meta.description: A year ago I started an ambitious project to create build 12 profitable small businesses. Now, a year later, I have a bunch of learnings under my belt.
meta.title: A Year of Making Is Done

title: TokenBird
b
i
(CoinMarketCap for NFTs). NFT project tracker. Made together with two friends. Only lasted one day before I knew I would shut it down.
Napchart
b
a
https://napchart.com/
. Service I already made 5 years ago, 150 daily visitors. Monetized it by adding premium. Earned 613.51$ so far. Love this project no matter the money. Will keep running it.
TokenBird
b
i
(NFT API). Made to solve my own need when making NFT websites (
a
https://rudeboys.io/
a
https://holoworld.io/
). Already had me as a customer.
Launch House is a new take on traditional business accelerators and universities. In the new modern world, you can get all information online. The important thing to focus on is relationships.
This comment on HN resonated with me and left me a bit discouraged:

Iâ€™m still thinking of what to do next year, but Iâ€™ll probably continue working in the Web3 space. Maybe Iâ€™ll go all-in on TokenBird, or Iâ€™ll join another startup. Iâ€™ll focus on finding good people to work with and seek to be part of good communities.
MediaChopper
b
a
https://mediachopper.io/
. App to solve an extremely rare edge case in Davinci Resolve. No one ever used it.
Videofly
b
a
https://videofly.io/
. Video transformation on the fly. Currently only used by me on a bunch of my projects. Almost got some big NFT sites to use it, but almost doesnâ€™t cut it.
Indie hacking is intristically lonely, other things are intristically not-lonely.
Even if you can build things quickly
(example: building an authentication system)
i
, you will end up having all that code to maintain months down the road.
FileParty
b
a
https://fileparty.co/
. (0$). This gets 40-50 daily visitors, but barely works. No monetization. I feel
watchparty.me
a
http://watchparty.me/
is better. Will probably shut down.
LarsList
b
a
https://larslist.org/
. List of people named Lars. Costs 5$ to add yourself. Earned 132.50$. The most fun project.

I guess this comment made me feel less unique. In dark times I start to question if the things I make even matter. It can be hard to feel like you build meaningful stuff when you only have a few weeks.
A year ago I started
12 startups in 12 months
a
https://larskarbo.no/12-startups-12-months/
, where I set out to build 12 profitable small businesses in 12 months.
I would rather celebrate a victory together with a group of friends or co-workers, than sitting alone with my stripe revenue and MRR numbers.
A Year of Making Is Done

Somewhere in between number 6 or 7 â€” when I still tried to maintain them all â€” I realized something about simplicity. When you have 7 projects you need to maintain and update regularly, you start to understand that things need to be simple to work.
A year ago I started an ambitious project to create build 12 profitable small businesses. Now, a year later, I have a bunch of learnings under my belt.
This experience made me realize how important community is. Having deep connections to people around you makes life so much more fun and meaningful.
I havenâ€™t lost the appeal of building things, but a lot of the indie hacking appeal has left me.
This year has been a great experience. I am happy and proud of myself for finishing it.
In the last month of 2021 I had the pleasure of living with 20 other founders in Launch House in LA.
It seems like most people who have started similar projects stop after two or three. I am happy I finished them all.
Thanks to everyone who supported me on the way. Especially
Monica Lent
a
https://twitter.com/monicalent
12x group
a
https://12xstartup.com/
and everyone at
Launch House
a
https://launchhouse.co/
Most of the projects were scratching-my-own-itch problems that I could solve with a website or an app.
Slapper
b
a
https://slapper.io/
. Service to loop, and collect segments from Spotify and Youtube. Got 2 paying subscribers, earned 81.90$ in total. Shut it down.
Personate
b
a
https://personate.ai/
. AI video generation. Made together with
another lars
a
https://twitter.com/vagneslars
. Got a 7000$ B2B pilot client. Had traction but lost it. At the end of the day, the whole product (vision) felt spammy. Shut it down.
Case Shortcut
b
a
https://caseshortcut.com/
. Mac app for a global shortcut to change text case. Cost 5$. Nobody bought.
Imitate
b
a
https://goimitate.com/

. French Pronunciation method I made. Got shoutout on a newsletter. Upsold 25 for premium course access. Earned 624$. Stale ever since. I broke up with my French girlfriend and am therefore not motivated for French anymore. Shut down.
I spent 2-6 weeks on most of the projects, and aimlessly tried to maintain and improve them for some more months before getting overwhelmed and shutting them down.
The motivation behind it was to try as many ideas as possible and build the necessary skills for succeeding at creative passive income projects.
You canâ€™t really talk about indie hacking without talking about life design.
TokenBird
b
a
https://tokenbird.io/
(NFT Marketplace). Third TokenBird pivot. Decentralized NFT marketplace. Got 3 ETH in presales for access to the platform. Still working on this. It has potential.

meta.title: Helication - Doing Nothing as a Productivity Strategy

title: Take a virtual helicopter out of the trenches, and you will see opportunities, roads and possibillities you never knew existed.
Stay in the helicopter for some time. Your brain needs time to readjust and let go.
Working on details will give you tunnel vision. You should give your intuition the best chance possible to see the next opportunities.

caption: A Black Hawk with a shower inside. Is this the perfect setup for a Helication?
title: shower-helicopter.png

For me, coding can be an extremely mind focusing activity. Especially if I get frustrated when solving a problem. Before I know it, my head is buried deep into a problem space and Iâ€™m not able to be present and see external opportunities.
Work is like being in the trenches. Nowhere to hide, nowhere to relax. Always things to do, always problems to fix. The only way to get out is to be rescued by a helicopter.
It sounds weird, but sometimes the best thing to do is to
do nothing
i
. In periods of life when you are assessing your next opportunities, step away from things that keep you busy.
A Year of Making Is Done

During my Helication, I have had to accept to see things burn. There are applications with bugs, client websites with flaws, and people desperately needing my help to fix â€œsmall problemsâ€. A strict â€œnoâ€ is the only thing that works here.

As you hang on to the rope on your way up, you will see more and more of the landscape around you. You will see how different the landscape, different objects, and movements connect and interact. Maybe youâ€™ll see some things burning, and get an urge to jump down and fix it. Like an itch you shouldnâ€™t scratch. Even further up you might see a great opportunity somewhere. The urge to jump down and start the new project is even stronger. But you need to hold on to the rope all the way up.
Helication - Doing Nothing as a Productivity Strategy

Well, I don't mean doing nothing like just staring at the wall. Forever. But at least for this in-between period I should do as little as possible. Some activities just take away too much of your grand-perspective, horizon, opportunity-seeking abilities. Some activities need to be forcibly shut down in a period like this.

Sometime, the only way to solve a problem is to get out and do something else. Your brain works differently when it is focused on something and when its not. This is why you so often get good ideas in the shower.
After finishing
12 startups in 12 months
a
/8711af9b325448b89b35f8d6be011914

, I was struck by one big question: "what the heck should I do now?" Choose one of the projects and go all-in? Find a company or startup to work for? As I was sitting nervously on my couch thinking about this newfound problem, I had a realization. The best thing might be to
do nothing
i

Taking a helication means properly retreating, regrouping and completely reassessing possible next steps in the periods between jobs. If you fail to take a proper break, there is a chance you never got out of your rabbit hole, and could therefore not see the opportunities you had.
I have a serious problem of always wanting to working on a bunch of small projects. Having multiple balls in the air has become my default.
I have found
interacting with
i
people
i

to be the ultimate horizon widening and opportunity generating mechanism. Ping your network, hang out with different people, talk to friends, host dinners. Interacting with people is a great way to discover different opportunities and feed your intuition with all kinds of new ideas and ways to look at things.
A Focused Mind donâ€™t see Opportunities
Clean article view
b
. The article styling should make reading as easy as possible. The article design should be clean and user friendly. Donâ€™t get in the way.

Design does not matter, but unique design and good content can make the site memorable. I have created a little corner of the internet now that I feel comfortable and at home in. Would love to write and create this space further now.
How custom should I do it?
My current blog is pretty simple and clear. But I want something more unique. Something that gives more of a â€œwowâ€ and â€œweirdâ€ response.

caption: The current blog design is clean, but I think it could be better and more unique.
title: Untitled
Icons.
b
I get inspired by Notion. The small icons next to articles gives them more life, and makes the whole thing feel more interactive, for some reason.
Some good examples are
Josh W Comeau
a
https://www.joshwcomeau.com/css/custom-css-reset/
and
Gwern
a
https://gwern.net
. They have excellent content and really thought-through, unique design.
Front page overview
b
. Iâ€™d like a nice way to show an overview over the content on the front page. Maybe Iâ€™ll make a organized web structure optimized for desktop screens? Iâ€™ll see.
Now I am ready to do some technical and design work. I feel I deserve it now. Finally I can dive into tweaking details and optimizing pages.
I am very happy that I spent my time writing content instead of procastinating on details like this since starting to write here. The last 18 months I have written 19 posts. Some have been good.
For example, it might be tempting to add structured data like
tags
i
or
icons
i
. But that means you need to support that for all articles you write in the future. The more work it takes to support that feature, the higher the likelyhood of the feature being discontinued.

As a general principle, I donâ€™t think itâ€™s important to focus on blog design. Itâ€™s just one of those things itâ€™s easy to end up doing instead of writing. Actually writing. Itâ€™s so easy to spend all time and energy on finding the perfect framework, doing SEO optimizations and creating the right design. And then you never got to the writing part.
I think it is important to keep things simple and focus on the core data formats of a blog article.
How should I design my blog?

Good content + unique design = a brand people will remember. If the content is bad, a unique design will just make it worse. People will see that you are terrible at prioritizing. At the other hand: having excellent content and bad/boring design doesnâ€™t matter. Like Paul Graham has.
If I make some custom funny animations, or custom components for my website, they will probably be replaced sometime in the future.
